###Question 1: Do you need state?

If so, then you should probably use a class. In fact, for most use-cases, particularly if you are new to object-oriented programming, if what you are trying to do should be done with a class.

When thinking of your program, think first in terms of what objects are necessary for you to create the interactions required. Methods that for whatever reason do not form an object that should be instantiated can be contained within a class.

###Question 2: Could this be done with a few singleton class methods on an existing class?

While oftentimes overused, class methods can be a better alternative.

###Question 3: Will this be helpful in multiple classes?

Modules provide mixin functionality and allow you to extend the same logic to multiple classes.
